{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox rail accident |title = Viareggio derailment |image = 2009 Viareggio train explosion 01.jpg |caption = |date = 29 June 2009 |time = 23:48 [[UTC+2]] |location = [[Viareggio railway station]],
[[Viareggio]] ([[Province of Lucca|LU]]) |coordinates = {{coord|43|52|16.21|N|10|15|23.13|E|source:nlwiki_region:IT_type:event|display=inline,title}} |location-dist = |location-dist-mi = |location-dir = |location-city = |country = Italy |line = [[Pisa]]–[[La Spezia]]–[[Genoa]] |operator = [[Ferrovie dello Stato]] (FS) (locomotive) / [[General American Transportation Corporation|GATX]] (wagons) |type = Derailment |cause = Defective axle |trains = 1 |pax = 0 |deaths = 32{{cite web|url=http://iltirreno.gelocal.it/dettaglio/addio-a-elisabeth-la-trentaduesima-vittima/1811061Viareggio |title=Addio a Elisabeth la trentaduesima vittima |publisher=Il Tirreno |language=Italian |date=22 December 2009 |accessdate=22 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091225180620/http://iltirreno.gelocal.it/dettaglio/addio-a-elisabeth-la-trentaduesima-vittima/1811061Viareggio |archivedate=25 December 2009 }} |injuries = 26 |damage = Areas near railway station seriously damaged by fire }} The '''Viareggio derailment''' was the [[derailment]] of a freight train and subsequent fire which occurred on 29 June 2009 in [[Viareggio railway station|a railway station]] in [[Viareggio]], [[Province of Lucca|Lucca]], a city in [[Central Italy]]'s [[Tuscany]] region. Thirty-two people were killed,{{cite web|url=http://it.reuters.com/article/topNews/idITMIE56100W20090702|title=Viareggio, salgono a 18 le vittime del disastro|language=Italian|publisher=''[[Reuters]]''|date=2 July 2009|accessdate=2 July 2009}} and a further twenty-six were injured == Details == [[File:2009 Viareggio train explosion fire.jpg|thumb|left|Some cars parked near the railway line burn]] Freight train No. 50325 from [[Trecate]] to [[Gricignano di Aversa|Gricignano]],{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2009/06/sezioni/cronaca/viareggio-treno/viareggio-treno/viareggio-treno.html |title=Viareggio, treno esplode in stazione. E' strage in fiamme auto e palazzi: 14 morti, 3 dispersi |publisher=''[[la Repubblica]]'' |language=Italian |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=1 July 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j6AxuTTh?url=http://www.repubblica.it/2009/06/sezioni/cronaca/viareggio-treno/viareggio-treno/viareggio-treno.html|archivedate=17 August 2009|deadurl=no}} hauled by [[FS Class E656|Class E655 locomotive]] E 655 175 with 14 [[Tank car#bogie tank wagons|tank wagons]]{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8127163.stm |title=Aerial footage of train blast aftermath |publisher=''[[BBC News]]''|date=30 June 2009|accessdate=30 June 2009}} was derailed at Viareggio at 23:48 [[UTC+2|local time]] (21:48 [[Coordinated universal time|UTC]]) on 29 June 2009.{{cite web|url=http://pdb.era.europa.eu/safety_docs/naib/view.aspx?id=1409 |title=INVESTIGATION NOTIFICATION |publisher=[[European Railway Agency]] |accessdate=22 September 2009}} Of the 14 wagons, the first wagon was registered by [[Polish State Railways|Polskie Koleje Państwowe]], the other 13 wagons by [[Deutsche Bahn]] (DB){{cite web |url=http://www.fsnews.it/cms/v/index.jsp?vgnextoid=b7170387bbe22210VgnVCM1000003f16f90aRCRD |title=Grave incidente nella stazione di Viareggio |publisher=''Ferrovie dello Stato (press release) |language=Italian |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=1 July 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j6B86ApJ?url=http://www.fsnews.it/cms/v/index.jsp?vgnextoid=b7170387bbe22210VgnVCM1000003f16f90aRCRD |archivedate=17 August 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} The first DB-registered wagon, No. 338078182106, which was owned by [[General American Transportation Corporation|GATX Rail Austria GmbH]] derailed on plain track in Viareggio station. The wagon hit the platform of the station and overturned to the left. The next four wagons also overturned and the two following were derailed but remained upright. The last seven wagons were not derailed, remaining intact on the track. The derailed wagons crashed into houses alongside the railway line. Some of the wagons were owned by KVG Kesselwagen, a division of GATX, and leased to [[ExxonMobil]] and [[Edoardo Raffinerie Garrone|ERG]] (the owners of the oil refinery where the train left),{{cite web|url=http://www.tgcom.mediaset.it/cronaca/articoli/articolo453849.shtml |title=Treno esploso, almeno 14 morti |language=Italian |publisher=''[[TGCOM]]'' |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=1 July 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j6B8Uc2S?url=http://www.tgcom.mediaset.it/cronaca/articoli/articolo453849.shtml|archivedate=17 August 2009|deadurl=no}} were reported to have been carrying [[Liquefied Petroleum Gas]] (LPG).{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Italy-Train-Gas-Tank-Explosion-Kills-Several-Derailed-Carriage-Causes-Explosion-Near-Viareggio/Article/200906415323889?lpos=World_News_Carousel_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15323889_Italy_Train_Gas_Tank_Explosion_Kills_Several%3A_Derailed_Carriage_Causes_Explosion_Near_Viareggio |title=Deadly Train Gas Tank Explosion in Italy |publisher=''[[Sky News]]'' |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=30 June 2009}} Two of these exploded and caught fire. Seven people were reported to have been killed when a house collapsed.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8125644.stm |title=Italians killed as train explodes |publisher=''[[BBC News]]'' |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=30 June 2009}} An eighth person who was killed was reported to have been riding a [[Scooter (motorcycle)|scooter]] on a road adjoining the railway. A child was found [[carbonization|carbonised]] in a car in front of the house where he lived with his parents. It is speculated that his parents put him in the car to save him and then returned to the house to save other two children.{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2009/06/sezioni/cronaca/viareggio-treno/soccorsi-e-polemica/soccorsi-e-polemica.html |title=La tragedia dei bambini: uno salvato un altro carbonizzato in un'automobile |publisher=''[[la Repubblica]]'' |language=Italian |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=30 June 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j6AwxqKD?url=http://www.repubblica.it/2009/06/sezioni/cronaca/viareggio-treno/soccorsi-e-polemica/soccorsi-e-polemica.html|archivedate=17 August 2009|deadurl=no}} The two members of the train crew suffered minor injuries in the accident. A large area{{vague|date=October 2017}} of Viareggio was damaged in the subsequent fires caused by the wagons carrying LPG [[Spontaneous combustion|self-combusting]]. Twenty-six people were reported to have been injured in the accident. The accident is the worst rail accident in Italy since the [[List of rail accidents (1970–1979)#1978|collision between two trains]] in [[Murazze di Vado]] near [[Bologna]] on 15 April 1978, which killed 48 people.{{cite web |url=http://quotidianonet.ilsole24ore.com/2005/01/07/5366640-TRAGEDIA-SUI-BINARI-.shtml |title=Tragedia sui Binari |publisher=''[[Quotidiano.net]]'' |language=Italian |date=7 January 2004 |accessdate=2 July 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j6BFPSDH?url=http://quotidianonet.ilsole24ore.com/2005/01/07/5366640-TRAGEDIA-SUI-BINARI-.shtml |archivedate=17 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} It was reported that a whole street had been destroyed in the explosion and fire.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8126235.stm |title=Eye-witness: My cousin was killed |publisher=''[[BBC News]]'' |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=30 June 2009}} == Aftermath == A state of emergency was declared by local authorities. Around 1,000 residents of Viareggio were evacuated from their homes as a result of the accident.{{cite web|url=http://uk.news.yahoo.com/4/20090630/twl-rail-crash-inferno-kills-15-in-north-41f21e0.html |title=Rail crash inferno kills 15 in northern Italy |publisher=''[[ITN]]'' |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=30 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703132638/http://uk.news.yahoo.com/4/20090630/twl-rail-crash-inferno-kills-15-in-north-41f21e0.html |archivedate=3 July 2009 }} Italian Prime Minister [[Silvio Berlusconi]] visited Viareggio "to take control of the situation", but he received boos and cries of "go home".{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/apocalypse-on-railway-in-tuscany-1726203.html |title='Apocalypse' on railway in Tuscany |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |date=1 July 2009 |accessdate=1 July 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j6B4bmPg?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/apocalypse-on-railway-in-tuscany-1726203.html|archivedate=17 August 2009|deadurl=no | location=London | first=Michael | last=Day}} Dr Enrico Petri, an eyewitness and local hospital physician, said that 36 people had been taken to Versilia Hospital in Viareggio suffering from 80–90% burns. He compared the aftermath to a terrorist attack. The accident left around 100 people homeless.{{cite web|url=http://uk.news.yahoo.com/18/20090630/twl-italian-train-inferno-kills16-ff57814.html |title=Italian train inferno kills 16 |publisher=''[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]'' |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=30 June 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The accident resulted in the disruption of rail services between Rome and [[Genoa]]. Viareggio railway station was partially reopened on 3 July 2009.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8132616.stm|title=Italian train crash toll up to 22. |publisher=[[BBC News Online]]|date=3 July 2009|accessdate=3 July 2009}} == Cause == The Direzione Generale per le Investigazioni Ferroviarie, a section of [[Ferrovie dello Stato]] (FS) opened an investigation into the cause of the accident.In Italy, FS is the [http://www.onnettomuustutkinta.fi/uploads/rdpaocg1rpk.pdf investigating body for railway accidents] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090704102830/http://www.onnettomuustutkinta.fi/uploads/rdpaocg1rpk.pdf |date=4 July 2009 }} Italian police said that the accident may have been caused by damaged tracks or a problem with the brakes on the train. Italian union [[Italian General Confederation of Labour|CGIL]] is reported to have blamed the decrepit state of the rolling stock, the maintenance of the wagon was the responsibility of [[General American Transportation Corporation|GATX]].{{cite web |url=http://www.fsnews.it/cms/v/index.jsp?vgnextoid=5db14af493232210VgnVCM1000003f16f90aRCRD |title=Carro sviato: la manutenzione spettava alla società proprietaria |publisher=Ferrovie dello Stato |language=Italian |accessdate=23 July 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j6BG6joM?url=http://www.fsnews.it/cms/v/index.jsp?vgnextoid=5db14af493232210VgnVCM1000003f16f90aRCRD |archivedate=17 August 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} The failure of an axle on the wagon that derailed is being investigated as a possible cause.{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2006/05/gallerie/cronaca/asse-viareggio/1.html |title= Incidente Viareggio, le foto dell'asse che ha ceduto |publisher=''[[la Repubblica]]'' |date= 30 June 2009 |accessdate=2 July 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j6B6wCuj?url=http://www.repubblica.it/2006/05/gallerie/cronaca/asse-viareggio/1.html|archivedate=17 August 2009|deadurl=no}} Pending the official conclusions of the commissions of inquiry the probable cause of the accident is attributable to structural failure of an axis of the carriage of the first tank wagon derailed. Italian Transport Minister [[Altero Matteoli]] informed the Italian Parliament on 1 July that a defective axle may have caused the accident. On 29 July 2009, an Extraordinary Network Meeting of the Network of National Safety Authorities was held.{{cite web|url=http://www.era.europa.eu/Pages/default.aspx |title=Extraordinary Network Meeting |publisher=European Railway Agency |accessdate=22 September 2009}} It invited members to disseminate information related to problems related to Type A Axles to railway operators, owners and keepers of freight wagons.{{cite web|url=http://www.era.europa.eu/core/Safety/Documents/our_products/cst-csm/Statement%2029th%20of%20July.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091014203543/http://www.era.europa.eu/core/Safety/Documents/our_products/cst-csm/Statement%2029th%20of%20July.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=14 October 2009 |title=The Network of National Safety Authorities (NSAs), convened at an extraordinary meeting on the 29th of July 2009 |publisher=European Railway Agency |accessdate=22 September 2009}} ==Prosecution== In 2016–17, thirty three people were tried in [[Lucca]] in connection with the derailment. Ten were acquitted. Former [[Rete Ferroviaria Italiana]] (RFI) and current [[Leonardo S.p.A.|Leonardo]] [[chief executive officer|CEO]] [[Mauro Moretti]] and former RFI CEO Michele Mario Ella, were convicted. Moretti was sentenced to seven years in prison for his role as CEO of RFI (2001-2006) but acquitted as CEO of [[Ferrovie dello Stato Italiane]] (FS) (2006-2014). Ella was sentenced to seven and a half years.{{cite web |url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/01/31/2-former-railway-execs-convicted-in-freight-train-explosion.html |title=2 former railway execs convicted in freight train explosion |publisher=Fox News |date=31 January 2017 |accessdate=1 February 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/italy-train-trial-moretti-idUKR1N1EG01Q |title=Italy court sentences former railway chief to 7 years in prison |publisher=Reuters |date=31 January 2017 |accessdate=1 February 2017}} == See also == {{Portalbar|2010s|Disasters|Italy}} * [[Lac-Mégantic rail disaster]] – a 2013 derailment of crude oil train and subsequent fire and explosions in the core of a Canadian town with 42 killed and another 5 presumed dead. * [[Nishapur train disaster]] – a 2004 derailment of a runaway fuel and flammable goods train in Iran, the resulting fire and explosion killed around 300 people. * [[Soham rail disaster]] – a 1944 fire and subsequent explosion of an ammunition train near Soham, England. * [[Expansion ratio]] * [[Moby Prince disaster]] == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{commons category|2009 Viareggio train accident}} {{wikinews|Rail explosion reported at Viareggio, Italy}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=REGENNkkvps Mobile phone footage of the fire] {{2009 railway accidents}} {{Railway accidents in Italy}} [[Category:2009 in Italy|Viareggio derailment]] [[Category:Viareggio|Train derailment (2009)]] [[Category:Railway accidents in 2009|Viareggio]] [[Category:Derailments in Italy|Viareggio]] [[Category:2009 fires|Viareggio]] [[Category:Fires in Italy]] [[Category:Accidents and incidents involving Ferrovie dello Stato Italiane]] [[Category:Gas explosions]] [[Category:June 2009 events]] [[Category:Train and subway fires]]

[[Image:Image mini.jpeg|thumb|Array in Palm Springs]] The '''Windstar [[vertical-axis wind turbine|vertical-axis]] [[wind turbine|turbine]]''' is a [[Lift (force)|lift]]-type device with straight blades attached at each end to a central rotating shaft. Windstar turbines were invented by Robert Nason Thomas and developed by Wind Harvest International, Inc., formerly the Wind Harvest Company, based in Point Reyes, California. Windstar turbines are operated as Linear Array Vortex Turbine Systems (LAVTS). Each rotor unit has a dual braking system of pneumatic disc brakes and [[blade pitch]]. All Windstar models use off-the-shelf generators, gearboxes, bearings and other components.
==History== In 2001 and 2002, three guyed prototype versions of the Windstar Model 530G were installed in [[Palm Springs, California]]. The Model 530G prototype used extruded aluminum blades, was supported by a guyed cable system and was rated at 25 kW. The three 530G turbines were placed in close proximity, creating the first Linear Array Vortex Turbine System (LAVTS). The 530G LAVTS was rated at 75 KW and was run continuously for five years to collect performance data.
In 2006, Wind Harvest International began design work on a series of Windstar turbine models to take advantage of the properties demonstrated in the 530G LAVTS prototype: Model 636, 1500 and 3000 turbines. The Model 636 is a direct evolution of the 530G, with an increase in blade length, in order to increase swept area, and including a modified bearing design. The 1500 and 3000 turbine models stand {{convert|50|ft}} high with a {{convert|40|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} rotor and 50-75 kW generators. The Windstar 1500 is {{convert|37.5|ft}} wide and is designed for higher wind speed locations. The Windstar 3000 will be {{convert|75|ft}} wide to operate better in lower wind speed locations (14-16 mph). Model 636 continues to use extruded aluminum blades, similar to the 530G. Models 1500 and 3000 use pultruded fiberglass blades.
By 2010, Windstar Model 636 turbines were placed on the transitional list for approved wind energy generation systems qualifying for the FIT (Feed-in-Tariff) energy pricing in the UK. In 2011, Wind Harvest International, Inc. began the process for MCS certification of the Model 636 LAVTS.
==Linear Array Vortex Turbine Systems== The Linear Array Vortex Turbine System (LAVTS) consists of three or more Windstar vertical-axis rotors, each with their own 25-75 kW generator, placed in a linear array with each rotor's blades passing within two feet of its neighbor. In this configuration, the center rotors gain an increase in energy output and efficiency. Observation of this effect (the coupled vortex effect) on Windstar turbines in field tests led to the issuance of US patent 6784566.
==Coupled Vortex Effect== Windstar turbines are built in arrays of three or more turbines in order to take advantage of the "coupled vortex effect." The coupled vortex effect was identified through field tests of Windstar 530G turbines and is made possible by the fact that straight-bladed vertical axis wind turbine blades passing in close proximity to one another in opposite directions create lift and torque on their neighboring blades, boosting the energy production of an array in comparison with a single turbine's performance. See patent {{US patent|6784566|US6784566}}. A mathematical model of the phenomenon and its effect on Windstar turbine performance was made possible by grant funds from the California Energy Commission in 2010.,<ref>http://www.energy.ca.gov/.../2010-07-28_research_awards_main-release.html</ref><ref>de Vries, Eize. "Array type vertical-axis wind turbine performance breakthrough," WindStats, June 2010.</ref> Research on similar vertical axis turbine configurations have independently confirmed the effect, linking the phenomenon's boost of performance to the fluid efficiency observed in schools of fish.<ref>Whittlesey RW, Liska SC, Dabiri JO (2010) "Fish schooling as a basis for vertical-axis wind turbine farm design," Bioninspiration and Biomimetics 5:035005.</ref>
==Windstar Model 636== Windstar Model 636 is a commercial model of the Windstar turbine offered by Wind Harvest International, Inc. It is a direct evolution of their earlier guyed model the 530G. It uses similar components with some modifications geared toward the commercial market. Modifications of the design include longer blades and a new bearing assembly.
==Windstar Models 1500 and 3000== These two models were designed based on field data from the 530G prototype field testing in the LAVTS configuration. Mathematical modeling of these turbines was conducted by IOPARA, Inc., made possible by a grant from the California Energy Commission in 2010. Model 3000 will stand 50 ft high with a 40 ft tall rotor. The Windstar Model 3000 will be 75 ft wide and used for lower wind speed locations (14-16 mph). The Windstar Model 1500 will have a similar rotor height and will be 37.5 ft wide. The Model 1500 is designed for higher wind speed locations.
